bibl.title: Letter from Selskar M. Gunn to Frederick F. Russell, September 7, 1922

div1.p: Gunn reports on a vaccine shipment and on new cases of yellow fever in the Ivory Coast.

div1.head: Letter from Selskar M. Gunn to Frederick F. Russell, September 7, 1922
div1.opener:
C O P Y
I. H. B.
History
Africa,
3, rue de Berri (VIII)
Paris
September 7, 1922
Dr. Frederick F. Russell
The Rockefeller Foundation
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York City.
Dear Russell:
div1.p:
I am leaving for my vacation tonight. I feel
satisfied that the shipment of vaccine and serum will be
transported to Bordeaux properly. We have a man who will
meet the “Chicago” with a protable refrigerator. I presume
that technical instructions for the use of these products
will come by mail on the “Olympic” or be found with the serum.

I have just had an interview with Mr. Antonetti,
Governor of the Ivory Coast, who tells me that cable reports
indicate several new cases within the last few days, but
no more deaths. The request for pieces of tissue in formalin
has already been sent by cable by the French authorities to
Grand Bassam. Mr. Antonetti assures me that the Foundation
will receive thorough and complete scientific reports if the
need for the material still exists when it arrives.

Cable information from Grand Bassam indicates that
the disease was imported into the district by an Italian who
came from the Gold Coast.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, (Signed) Selskar M. Gunn
Director. SMG-H
